top_categories.workout_context: At mile 60 of 130, glycogen is gone. This workout teaches your body to produce watts on fumes.
Dirty Reiver's Forest gravel roads (two-track), Fist-size embedded rocks forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 130 miles.
Race-pace efforts that mimic Dirty Reiver's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before April.
108ft/mi means long efforts at or near FTP on every climb. If your threshold cracks at minute 15, you'll walk the rest.
At Dirty Reiver, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
14,100ft of climbing means repeated surges above threshold. VO2max work is how you survive the fifth climb, not just the first.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At Dirty Reiver, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of Dirty Reiver. Train it until it feels boring.
14,100ft of climbing on grades that change every minute. You need to switch from seated to standing without losing rhythm.
Short, max efforts are unavoidable. Punchy climbs, gap closures, attacks on forest gravel roads with technical singletrack. If you haven't trained them, you'll crack.
Every hard session works better with a bigger aerobic base. At 130 miles, base fitness is the difference between racing and surviving.
130 miles rewards fat oxidation. This volume work shifts your fuel mix so you're still burning fat at hour 5, not bonking at hour 3.

race_overlay.heat: April in Kielder, Northumberland, England can bring heat. Complete 3–4 heat exposure sessions in the final 2 weeks before Dirty Reiver. Increase sodium intake 48 hours before race day.
race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for Dirty Reiver’s 130 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Dirty Reiver demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride forest gravel roads with technical singletrack at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: forest gravel roads (two-track), fist-size embedded rocks, rocky mountain-style forest roads. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 130 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Durability, Gravel Specific, and Race Simulation to prepare you for 130 miles of forest gravel roads with technical singletrack in Kielder, Northumberland, England.
